title-group.article-title: Extension of an operating load range of a four-cylinder gasoline homogeneous charge compression ignition engine via a blowdown supercharge system, aiming at in-cylinder thermal stratification

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, Chiba University, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Tatsuya Kuboyama, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, 1-33 Yayoi-Cho, Inage-Ku, Chiba, Japan 263-8522. Email: tkuboyam@faculty.chiba-u.jp

abstract.p: In order to extend the operational range with a gasoline fueled multi-cylinder homogeneous charge compression ignition engine, a blowdown supercharge system and an exhaust gas recirculation guide was developed. The concept was to provide a large amount of diluted mixture and a strong in-cylinder thermal stratification for decreasing nitrogen oxide emissions and pressure rise rate during high-load homogeneous charge compression ignition operation. Secondary air injection was also proposed to reduce a cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing, which is one of the limiting factors of multi-cylinder homogeneous charge compression ignition operation. In advance of experimental works, the blowdown supercharge system and the exhaust gas recirculation guide were proved to be effective to reduce pressure rise rate for high-load operation using three-dimensional in-cylinder flow simulations and zero-dimensional multi-zone simulations with detailed chemical kinetics. Based on the simulation results, experiments were conducted using a slightly modified production four-cylinder gasoline engine. At first, the effects of the proposed techniques were experimentally investigated by focusing on one cylinder out of four. Then, a four-cylinder homogeneous charge compression ignition operation test using the new techniques was carried out. The one-cylinder measurements revealed that the blowdown supercharge system with an exhaust gas recirculation guide is capable of extending the homogeneous charge compression ignition operating range up to a net indicated mean effective pressure of 590 kPa for naturally aspirated conditions. In addition, secondary air injection was experimentally demonstrated as a technique for reducing a cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing. Reducing the cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing, four-cylinder homogeneous charge compression ignition operation with a net indicated mean effective pressure of 570 kPa was successfully achieved with the blowdown supercharge system and the exhaust gas recirculation guide.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Homogeneous charge compression ignition (HCCI) engines are based on a highly efficient and low nitrogen oxide (NOx) emission engine operating strategy. However, to apply HCCI operation to a production engine, several issues need to be addressed. The main issues of operating an engine in HCCI mode are the limited operational load range achievable and the difficulty in controlling ignition timing.

In order to achieve HCCI combustion using gasoline fuel, the in-cylinder temperature has to be increased to realize autoignition of the lean and diluted mixtures. Various techniques, such as intake air heating, variable compression ratio and a large amount of hot exhaust gas recirculation (EGR), have been demonstrated to obtain a high enough temperature to achieve autoignition at the appropriate timing. In recent studies, hot EGR gas obtained by using variable valve actuation has been widely used to control HCCI combustion.1 One of the most common methods to obtain a large amount of EGR gas is the negative valve overlap (NVO) method in which the burned gas trapped inside the cylinder is retained. Although the presented results are limited, the so-called rebreathing method, in which the exhaust gas is directly recharged from the exhaust manifold by reopening the exhaust valve during the intake stroke, is also a well-known technique.

Using a large amount of EGR gas to increase the in-cylinder mixture temperature decreases the amount of intake air, and the amount of diluted gas (consisting of air and EGR gas) also decreases because of the higher in-cylinder temperature. Due to a lack of the dilution gas, the in-cylinder pressure rise rate (dP/dθ) and NOx emissions increase with increasing load. At low-load conditions, combustion stability and combustion efficiency decrease, and CO and hydrocarbon (HC) emissions increase due to the decreases in fuel concentration and EGR gas temperature. As a result, HCCI operation is achieved only for a limited range of operating conditions. Figure 1 shows the HCCI operating range achieved with the NVO method and the operation area used under the Japanese 10-15 driving mode test cycle, which covers a typical urban driving pattern with a typical production vehicle.2 The vertical axis is gross indicated mean effective pressure (gross IMEP) and the horizontal axis is engine speed. It can be seen that the upper load limit of the HCCI operation using an engine with a compression ratio of 11.5 is about 400 kPa in gross IMEP at 1500 r/min. Similarly, Hiraya et al.3 showed the upper load limit of HCCI operation using the NVO method was an IMEP of 430 kPa. Fuerhapter et al.4 showed that the upper load limit using a rebreathing strategy was an IMEP of 470 kPa (gross or net IMEP is not specified in Hiraya et al.3 or Fuerhapter et al.4) In all cases, the HCCI operating range attained is much lower than that required in practical usage. Today, HCCI operation is seen as a part-load operation strategy, and switching to conventional spark-ignition (SI) operation at low and high loads is necessary.5 However, this dual mode operation reduces the advantage in fuel consumption of HCCI operation. Then, even though such a dual mode operation is used, extending the HCCI operating range and reducing the frequency of the combustion mode switching are important to promote HCCI combustion in practical usage.

sec.p: The upper load limit of gasoline HCCI combustion using a conventional approach is generally below a gross IMEP of 400 kPa.2 This limit is dependent on the maximum value of dP/dθ; that is, the knock intensity allowable for normal engine operation and NOx emissions, both of which are mainly governed by a steep heat-release rate and increase in in-cylinder gas temperature during combustion determined by the mass ratio of in-cylinder working gas to supplied fuel (G/F). Hiraya et al.3 pointed out that the G/F ratio required for the HCCI operation with an acceptable level of dP/dθ and NOx emissions is more than 30. Therefore, providing a large amount of working gas in the cylinder is important to realize high-load HCCI operation without increasing dP/dθ and NOx emissions. Supercharging is widely used to extend the upper load limit. Hyvönen et al.6 demonstrated HCCI operation at a brake mean effective pressure (BMEP) of 1000 kPa using a turbocharger. However, it must be noted that the maximum in-cylinder pressure rise rate (dP/dθmax) was 1850 kPa/° in Hyvönen et al.,6 which is beyond the acceptable level. Urata et al.2 showed that the upper load limit defined by knocking was extended up to a gross IMEP of 650 kPa without an increase in NOx emissions by using a supercharger with the NVO strategy. Furthermore, supercharged gasoline HCCI operation at a gross IMEP of 1.6 MPa was attained by Dec and Yang.7 However, when using a mechanical supercharger, brake thermal efficiency deteriorates and maximum BMEP decreases due to the high mechanical loss of superchargers.6,8 In addition, a turbocharger would not be effective for HCCI operation because providing effective intake boost pressure using a turbocharger is difficult due to the low exhaust energy of HCCI combustion. Takanashi et al.9 developed an inter-cylinder EGR boost (ICEB) system to obtain a large amount of dilution gas without an external supercharger. The upper load limit, defined by dP/dθmax of 400 kPa/°, was extended up to a gross IMEP of 600 kPa using the ICEB system. However, this system is difficult to apply to a production engine because the fully variable valve actuation with a large degree of freedom and the special exhaust system used in this system require complex construction in the hardware and controlling system.

For reducing dP/dθmax to extend the upper load limit, stratified distributions of fuel concentration10–12 and temperature13–20 have been widely examined. Direct fuel injection has been applied to provide in-cylinder fuel stratification. Sjöberg and Dec10 experimentally and numerically investigated the effect of fuel stratification on dP/dθ using several kinds of fuels that had different research octane numbers (RON). The results showed that partial fuel stratification was effective, with the fuel exhibiting some amount of heat release by low-temperature oxidation; however, partial fuel stratification is unlikely to be effective with fuel with little heat release by low-temperature oxidation, such as regular gasoline, because of low sensitivity of ignition timing to equivalence ratio.11 Aroonsrisopon et al.12 also showed that the engine performance, in terms of exhaust emissions and dP/dθ was not improved by fuel stratification for high-load conditions using the fuel with a 91.8 RON. Urata et al.2 applied direct fuel injection during the late stage of the compression stroke for retarding ignition timing and reducing dP/dθmax for high-load operation. The combustion timing was retarded and the upper load limit, as defined by knocking, was successfully extended. However, NOx emissions largely increased due to slightly stratified fuel concentration.

In-cylinder thermal stratification has been shown to possibly reduce dP/dθmax and to extend the upper load limit of HCCI operation. Sjöberg and Dec13–16 investigated the effect of in-cylinder thermal stratification, mainly generated by heat transfer between the cylinder wall and the in-cylinder mixture, on dP/dθmax by experimental and numerical methods. The potential of the in-cylinder thermal stratification for reducing dP/dθmax was quantitatively demonstrated using a multi-zone chemical kinetics model. Multi-zone analysis revealed that by providing a wider temperature distribution of the core of the in-cylinder mixture, the combustion duration was prolonged and the pressure rise rate decreased.14 It was also experimentally revealed that thermal stratification within the bulk gas controls dP/dθmax and that the temperature distribution generated by heat transfer to the cylinder wall plays a smaller role in reducing dP/dθmax.16 It is considered that to generate a large thermal stratification within the bulk gas zone, techniques to reduce mixing between the relatively low-temperature intake mixture and the hot EGR gas are required. However, insufficient mixing between the fresh air–fuel mixture and EGR gas provides a spatial distribution of in-cylinder mixture composition.17,18 Krasselt et al.19 and Herold et al.20 investigated the effect of in-cylinder stratifications of temperature, fuel concentration, air–fuel mass ratio (A/F) and specific heat ratio on dP/dθusing a single-cylinder engine and an optical engine. The results revealed that the effect of the stratification of in-cylinder mixture temperature on dP/dθ could be canceled out by the competing effect of the distributions of fuel concentration and A/F. From these results, it is suggested that in-cylinder stratification should not be introduced into a production engine because the magnitude of stratification maintained until combustion commences is quite limited and the temperature stratification is accompanied by distributions of fuel concentration and A/F. By contrast, the simulation results carried out by Babajimopoulos17,18 using three-dimensional (3D) simulations of in-cylinder flow and multi-zone chemical kinetics showed that, even though the distribution of equivalence ratio has a competing effect against the effect of temperature distribution on ignition, the temperature distribution is still the dominant factor that determines ignition timing.

The new combustion concept, the so-called spark-ignition–compression-ignition (SI–CI) combustion combined with flame propagation and autoignition has been proposed as a technique to obtain a wide operating range.21–23 In this technique, SI combustion of the slightly stratified mixture is followed by autoignition of a homogeneous lean mixture. Since SI combustion is used as a trigger for the lean mixture’s autoignition, relatively low in-cylinder temperature is allowed to attain autoignition, and high volumetric efficiency of the intake mixture can be achieved. As a result, the upper load limit defined by knocking was extended up to an IMEP of 650 kPa (gross or net IMEP is not specified).21 However, an increase in NOx emissions due to SI combustion is an issue to be solved. Yun et al.23 also demonstrated high-load SI–CI operation at a net IMEP of 650 kPa. A stoichiometric mixture was used to utilize a three-way catalyst for reduction in NOx emissions. However, some of the attractive advantages of HCCI operation, such as extremely low NOx emissions and high thermal efficiency due to lean mixture combustion, were sacrificed in this approach.

Meanwhile, a cylinder-to-cylinder variation in combustion timing is also one of the limiting factors of the HCCI operating range for a multi-cylinder engine. In the four-cylinder HCCI test conducted by Flowers et al.,24 there was significant cylinder-to-cylinder variation in combustion timing, and the difference in combustion timing between cylinders increased with combustion timing retard. It is concluded that reducing the phase difference in combustion timing between the cylinders is necessary to achieve a higher BMEP. The benefit of reduction in the cylinder variation in combustion timing can be seen in Yun et al.25 A closed-loop control system, which controls the fuel injection duration and SI timing of each cylinder and the amount of external EGR gas, was developed to reduce the cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing of an SI–CI engine. It was found that the cylinder variation in air–fuel ratio significantly affected the cylinder variation in ignition timing. It was also shown that combustion phasing control could decrease the average ringing intensity, which is an indicator of the combustion noise associated with dP/dθmax without decreasing combustion stability by providing stable retarded combustion.

Overall, to extend the upper load limit of HCCI operation, a technique capable of obtaining a large amount of in-cylinder mixture would be necessary. In addition, providing a strong thermal stratification within the bulk gas zone would have significant potential for allowing much higher load HCCI operation by decreasing dP/dθmax. However, a practical method to provide a large in-cylinder thermal stratification has not yet been proposed. Additionally, reducing the cylinder-to-cylinder variation in combustion timing is also necessary to extend the operating range of multi-cylinder HCCI operation.

The objective of this study is to develop a practical technique to achieve multi-cylinder HCCI with a wide operating range. Experimental and numerical work was conducted, focusing on the extension of the high-load HCCI operating limit. A blowdown supercharge (BDSC) system and an EGR guide, which provide a large amount of intake air and EGR gas and a strong in-cylinder thermal stratification, were newly proposed and demonstrated. In advance of the experimental work, the effect of in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration provided by the BDSC system and the EGR guide on dP/dθmax was numerically investigated. Based on the simulation results, the effect of the proposed system on the high-load HCCI operating limit was experimentally examined using a slightly modified production gasoline engine. Additionally, the effects of a direct fuel injection and a cooling water temperature on the HCCI operating range were also investigated. Moreover, a practical technique that can control combustion timing was proposed and applied to reduce the cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing, which is one of the limiting factors of the operating range of the multi-cylinder HCCI engines.

sec.title: The BDSC system
sec.p: Using a conventional approach, the upper load limit of gasoline HCCI combustion is generally below an IMEP of 400 kPa.2 This limit is dependent on the maximum value of dP/dθ; that is, the knock intensity allowable for normal engine operation and NOx emissions, both of which are governed by combustion temperature and steep heat-release rates.

The concept of the BDSC system is to obtain a large amount of diluted mixture without an external supercharger. Figure 2(a) shows the idea of a four-cylinder BDSC system. This system has a 4–2–1 exhaust system, which is common for high-performance production engines. The exhaust system is divided into two groups of cylinders: 1 and 4, and 2 and 3. This configuration provides blowdown pulse separation for each pair of cylinders with 360° phase difference. Figure 2(b) shows an example of the valve timing used in the BDSC system. In the early stage of the compression stroke for cylinder 4, the exhaust valve of cylinder 1 opens, and the exhaust blowdown pressure wave from cylinder 1 causes an increased pressure in the exhaust system. When the exhaust valve of cylinder 4 opens again at this timing, some of the exhaust gas is recharged into cylinder 4 through the exhaust port by the high exhaust pressure wave propagated from cylinder 1.

caption.p: Concept of the BDSC: (a) configuration of four-cylinder BDSC system and (b) exhaust valve reopening for EGR gas recharging.

sec.p: The BDSC system allows the induction of a large amount of intake air–fuel mixture into the cylinder, since EGR gas is supercharged into the cylinder just after the end of the intake stroke, with no effect of volumetric efficiency. This allows an increased fuel supply. Furthermore, the total mass of in-cylinder diluted mixture increases because the EGR gas returns into the cylinder at high pressure. A large amount of diluted mixture avoids an increase in dP/dθ as well as an increase in NOx emissions due to relatively slow heat release and low combustion temperature.

sec.title: The EGR guide
sec.p: The in-cylinder thermal stratification is known to have a high potential for reducing dP/dθmax.13–16 In the present study, a device named an EGR guide was developed to generate strong in-cylinder thermal stratification. Figure 3 shows the geometry of the EGR guide installed on the surface of the cylinder head and the piston top. The EGR guide is used together with the BDSC system to generate thermal stratification. The EGR guide consists of half-circular rings attached on the edge of the exhaust ports and the piston head with a protuberant surface. The EGR guide controls the flow direction of EGR gas recharged through the exhaust port and prevents the relatively low temperature intake mixture and the high-temperature EGR gas from mixing, providing a strong thermal stratification inside the cylinder.

caption.p: EGR guide geometry.

sec.title: Valve timing
sec.p: The valve timings used in the BDSC system are shown in Figure 4. The exhaust valve timing was fixed, while intake and EGR valve timings were varied according to the target load. With increasing target load, intake valve closing timing retards and EGR valve opening timing advances. The intake valve lift is increased and the EGR valve lift is increased simultaneously when the target load is increased. The valve timings were varied by changing a pair of intake and exhaust valve camshafts. Three pairs of intake and exhaust valve camshafts were used for different target loads. The valve timings for each target load were numerically optimized for obtaining suitable in-cylinder temperature and fuel concentration, both of which allow lower fuel consumption, lower maximum in-cylinder temperature to avoid NOx production and sufficiently high in-cylinder temperature to allow suitable ignition timing. The optimization was carried out using a commercially available one-dimensional (1D) simulation code, GT-POWER, and an optimizer software, mode-FRONTIER. The details of the optimization have been reported previously.26

caption.p: Valve actuation strategy of the BDSC system.

sec.title: The secondary air injection system
sec.p: Controlling the ignition timing is one of the main issues of an HCCI engine. The EGR gas temperature strongly affects in-cylinder temperature. Therefore, ignition timing is supposed to be controlled by controlling EGR gas temperature appropriately.

A secondary air injection system was developed to control ignition timing, or combustion phasing. Figure 5 shows the configuration of the secondary air injection system. As shown in this figure, a commercially available gas fuel injector was installed in the exhaust manifold. Using the gas injector, relatively lower temperature air was injected into the exhaust gas before the EGR valve closing timing to lower the recharged EGR gas temperature. A gas injector has high responsivity to control the injection duration on the cycle by cycle basis.

caption.p: Schematic of the secondary air injection system.

sec.title: Test engine
sec.p: A 2.0-l four-cylinder production gasoline engine with a port fuel injection (PFI) system (Honda K20A) was used in the experiments. The basic specifications of the test engine are summarized in Table 1. The engine has a bore of 86 mm, a stroke of 86 mm and a displacement volume of 1998.2 cm3 (499.6 cm3/cylinder). The compression ratio of the base engine is 11.5.

caption.p: Test engine specifications.

sec.p: In the base engine, a variable valve timing and lift electronic control (VTEC) system was originally installed in the exhaust valve train. The exhaust VTEC was used to control EGR valve lift actuation to switch the operating mode between HCCI and SI, as shown in Figure 6. In the experiment, the engine was operated with SI mode without the EGR valve lift for warming up the engine components. After the warming-up run, the EGR valve lift was activated by exhaust VTEC to switch the engine operation mode from SI to HCCI. The exhaust manifold of the test engine was newly designed for the BDSC system based on 1D simulation results.26 To obtain a large exhaust blowdown pressure pulse, the diameter of the manifold was decreased from φ38 mm to φ30 mm, and the joint angle between the two exhaust pipes (θ in Figure 2) was changed to 180°. The compression ratio of the test engine was increased by changing the piston head geometry. The piston head, which had the EGR guide wall, was newly designed. For practical usage, HCCI operation would be used partially, switching to and from conventional SI operation, because the whole operation range in terms of load and speed is difficult to be covered with only the HCCI operation. Therefore, the compression ratio could not be increased so much. The piston head was designed with a target compression ratio of 12.0. The measured compression ratio was 11.4 for the piston head without the EGR guide, and 11.6 for that with the EGR guide, respectively.

caption.p: EGR valve lift activation control using the VTEC system.

sec.title: Direct fuel injection system
sec.p: A direct fuel injection system was also employed to investigate the effect of spatial distribution of fuel concentration on HCCI operating range. Figure 7 shows the injector mounting location and the fuel injection nozzle tip. The direct fuel injector has three φ0.115 mm nozzle orifices. The angle between each fuel spray is 30°. The direct injector was mounted under the intake port. Fuel was injected towards the high-temperature recharged EGR gas zone with an inclined angle of 35° from the horizontal axis. When the direct-injection (DI) system was applied with the EGR guide, the measured compression ratio was 11.8.

caption.p: Direct fuel injector location and injection nozzle tip.

sec.title: Measurement system
sec.p: Newly proposed techniques were tested by two-cylinder operation to evaluate the proposed systems. In the two-cylinder operation, only cylinders 4 and 1 were activated, and cylinders 2 and 3 were deactivated by stopping fuel supply and valve actuation. After the two-cylinder tests, the effect of cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing on the HCCI operating range was investigated during four-cylinder operation.

The cylinder pressures of all activated cylinders were measured by a piezoelectric pressure transducer (Kistler type 6052C or 6117B). A piezo-resistive pressure transducer (Kistler 4005A) was mounted on the exhaust manifold and on the intake manifold of cylinder 4. An exhaust throttle valve was additionally installed after the silencer to regulate the mean exhaust pressure. For exhaust emissions measurements, Fourier transform infrared spectrometer (FTIR) (HORIBA, MEXA 6000FT) was used for NOx (NO and NO2) and CO, and flame ionization detector (FID) (HORIBA, MEXA1170HFID) was used for unburned HC emissions.

The measurement and in-cylinder pressure analysis with the two-cylinder operation was conducted using cylinder 4, while that with the four-cylinder operation were conducted using all four cylinders. Indicated results are shown as net values, calculated on a 720° crank angle (CA) basis, unless otherwise noted (see Appendix 2).

sec.title: Experimental conditions
sec.p: Table 2 shows the base experimental conditions. All experiments were conducted with conditions shown in Table 2 unless otherwise noted. Engine speed was set at 1500 r/min. Intake air temperature was kept at 25°C and relative humidity was kept at 50% for all measurements. The coolant water temperature was 85°C. Conventional gasoline (RON 91) was used as a test fuel. The chemical composition of the test fuel is presented in Figure 8. For fuel injection, a PFI system was mainly used. The injection pressure for the PFI was set at 350 kPa (gauge). To obtain a well-mixed air–fuel mixture, the PFI was completed before intake valve opening. Fuel injection timing was set at 10° before intake top dead center (TDC).

sec.title: Definition of the limit of HCCI operation
sec.p: The limiting variables for HCCI operation are maximum pressure rise rate (dP/dθmax), NOx emissions and combustion stability. In the present study, an acceptable HCCI operation condition was defined as dP/dθmax≤ 400 kPa/°; coefficient of variation (COV) of IMEP ≤ 5%; and net indicated specific emissions of NOx (ISNOx) ≤ 0.1 g/kWh.

The acceptable dP/dθmax depends on the engine specifications and operating conditions. Ringing intensity,27 which correlates with dP/dθmax, has been widely used to define the upper load limit of HCCI operation. The ringing intensity corresponding to dP/dθmax of 400 kPa/° is about 2.0 for the experimental conditions of the present study.

sec.title: 3D simulations of in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration
sec.p: To investigate the effect of the spatial distributions of in-cylinder temperature and fuel concentration generated by the BDSC system with the EGR guide on dP/dθ, 3D numerical simulations of in-cylinder flow and zero-dimensional (0D) numerical simulations with detailed chemical kinetics were carried out. The 3D simulations were carried out using a commercial computation fluid dynamics code, STAR-CD, to investigate the effects of the EGR guide and the direct fuel injection on in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration. In the 3D numerical simulations, in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration were predicted from the beginning of the intake stroke to the end of the compression stroke with approximately 1.3 million computational cells. Ignition and combustion models were not implemented, and chemical reaction was not considered in these 3D simulations. The initial conditions and boundary conditions were given by the 1D engine cycle simulations using the commercial code GT-POWER.

sec.title: 0D multi-zone analysis with detailed chemical kinetics
sec.p: In the 0D chemical reaction simulations, to consider a stratified distribution of in-cylinder mixture in terms of temperature and fuel concentration, a multi-zone analysis was applied.14,28 In multi-zone analysis, the in-cylinder mixture is divided into a number of equal mass zones with regards to temperature and fuel concentration, which are predicted by 3D numerical simulations. 0D detailed chemical reactions are solved in each divided zone. Each zone has homogeneous temperature and chemical species concentrations. Heat release in each divided zone affects in-cylinder pressure. This indicates that the pressures in each zone are equal to the in-cylinder pressure. However, the chemical species and energy transfers between each divided zone were not considered. Sjöberg and Dec14 showed that five-zone analysis has enough accuracy to predict the dP/dθ of HCCI combustion. In the present study, in order to investigate the effect of spatial distributions of temperature and fuel concentration on dP/dθmax, the in-cylinder mixture was divided into 25 zones classified by temperature and fuel concentration. Firstly, the in-cylinder mixture was divided into five equal mass zones classified by the temperature distribution. Then, each temperature zone was divided again into five equal mass zones based on fuel concentration. In total, 25 zones were considered. Chemical reactions were solved by using a commercial code, DARS. A reaction model proposed by Golovichev29 was employed, in which 120 species and 619 reactions were considered.

sec.title: Extension of high-load operating limit of an HCCI engine using the BDSC system and EGR guide
Effect of EGR guide geometry on in-cylinder thermal stratification
sec.p: At first, the effect of EGR guide geometry on in-cylinder temperature distribution was numerically investigated to find an optimized geometry of the EGR guide. The simulated geometries are shown in Figure 9. The location of the EGR guide was examined. In Case 1, the EGR guide geometry was designed to utilize in-cylinder tumble flow as a means to enhance thermal stratification. In Case 2, the geometry was designed to guide the flow direction of the recharging EGR gas towards the cylinder wall for reducing mixing between EGR gas and the air–fuel mixture. In Case 3, the geometry was designed to guide the flow direction of the recharging EGR gas towards the center of the combustion chamber for reducing heat transfer between the EGR gas and the cylinder wall. Figure 10 shows simulation results. The cross-sectional views of the horizontal and vertical center axis of the combustion chamber are shown. It is found that the EGR guide geometry of Case 2 is more efficient than the other two geometries for generating thermal stratification. In Case 1, the temperature distribution is not affected by the tumble flow. It is also found that mixing between recharged EGR gas and intake air–fuel mixture is promoted around the center part of the cylinder. In Case 3, recharged EGR gas is well mixed with an air–fuel mixture around the center part of the cylinder, and the most homogeneous temperature distribution among the three tested cases is provided. In Case 2, high-temperature EGR gas does not distribute over the center part of the cylinder. Therefore, the mixing between recharged EGR and air–fuel mixture is successfully reduced.

caption.p: Simulated EGR guide locations.
Effect of the EGR guide location on in-cylinder temperature distribution (3D numerical simulations).

sec.p: In the temperature distribution of Case 2, it can be seen that hot EGR gas entering into the cylinder moves towards the piston crown along the side-wall surface of the cylinder. EGR gas goes along the piston surface from the exhaust port side towards the intake port side after arriving at the piston crown. From this result, it is considered that a much stronger thermal stratification could be generated by preventing the EGR gas from moving to the intake port side. Therefore, the piston head with a protuberant surface shown in Figure 3 was applied. Figure 11 shows the effect of the EGR guide on the in-cylinder temperature distribution. In the case with the EGR guide, both the circular rings on the exhaust port and the piston head with the protuberant surface shown in Figure 3 were applied. The cross sectional views of the horizontal and vertical center axis of the combustion chamber are shown. The upper images (Figure 11(a)) show the in-cylinder temperature distributions without the EGR guide. The lower images (Figure 11(b)) show the in-cylinder temperature distributions with the EGR guide. It can be seen that by attaching the EGR guide on the piston head, a high-temperature region successfully remains at only the exhaust port side in the cylinder. As a result, in-cylinder thermal stratification with the EGR guide is much stronger than that without the EGR guide. To estimate the thermal stratification quantitatively, a five-zone analysis was applied. In this method, the in-cylinder mixture was divided into five equal mass zones classified by the temperature distribution. The temperature difference (ΔT) between the highest temperature zone (zone 5) and the second lowest temperature zone (zone 2) was used as an indicator of the in-cylinder temperature stratification. To define the effect of the EGR guide on the thermal stratification, the lowest temperature zone (zone 1) that would be largely affected by the heat transfer between in-cylinder gas and the cylinder wall was not considered. In this method, a larger ΔT indicates a stronger thermal stratification. Figure 12 shows the effect of the EGR guide on temporal variation of ΔT. Prior to 60° before top dead center (BTDC), ΔT without the EGR guide is larger than that with the EGR guide. However, after 60° BTDC, ΔT with the EGR guide is larger than that without the EGR guide. From these results, it can be concluded that the EGR guide is effective for reducing the mixing between hot EGR gas and intake mixture.

caption.p: Effect of the EGR guide on in-cylinder temperature distribution (3D simulations): (a) without EGR guide and (b) with EGR guide.
Effect of the EGR guide on temperature difference between the high-temperature zone and low-temperature zone during the compression stroke (3D simulations).

sec.title: Effect of in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration on pressure rise rate
sec.p: To investigate the effect of in-cylinder stratifications of temperature and fuel concentration generated by the EGR guide on dP/dθmax, 0D multi-zone simulations with detailed chemical kinetics was carried out. In the simulations, the three cases shown in Table 3, which have different in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration, were examined. Regarding the temperature distribution, two different stratified temperature distributions were examined. The 3D numerical simulation results presented in the previous section showed that the BDSC system with the EGR guide generates a strong in-cylinder thermal stratification. Meanwhile, even though the EGR guide is not used, a relatively small in-cylinder thermal stratification would be formed by heat transfer between in-cylinder gas and the cylinder walls.30 Therefore, two temperature distributions, one generated by the EGR guide and the other by heat transfer, were examined to estimate the effect of the stratified EGR gas distribution on dP/dθ Regarding the fuel concentration distribution, a uniform distribution and a fuel distribution provided by the EGR guide were considered. Using PFI, an intake air–fuel mixture is expected to be fully premixed. However, using the BDSC system with the EGR guide, the mixing between a well-mixed air–fuel mixture and a recharged EGR gas is insufficient. Because there is a small amount of air–fuel mixture in a high-temperature zone, local fuel concentration in the high-temperature zone would be relatively lean. Namely, fuel concentration is also stratified using the EGR guide. The fuel concentration in the high-temperature zone, which consists of a large amount of EGR gas and a small amount of intake mixture, is relatively leaner than that in the low-temperature zone. Generally, ignition is advanced with increasing temperature, but retarded with decreasing fuel concentration. This implies that with the BDSC system and the EGR guide, the stratified fuel concentration may cancel out the effect of the in-cylinder temperature distribution on ignition.19,20 Therefore, the effect of the stratified fuel concentration generated by the BDSC system and EGR guide was examined. In Case 1, the uniform fuel concentration distribution and the temperature distribution stratified by the heat transfer were applied. In Case 2, distributions of fuel concentration and temperature generated by the EGR guide were applied. In Case 3, the temperature distribution with the EGR guide was applied, but fuel concentration distribution is uniform. Note that in Case 3, the fuel concentration (G/F) is spatially uniform, but A/F is stratified. In addition, it should be noted that the stratified temperature distribution used in Case 2 and Case 3 includes the effect of heat transfer to the wall, in addition to the effect of the EGR guide. The calculation was commenced from −120° after TDC (ATDC) and stopped at 40° ATDC. The initial conditions, such as in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel, were based on the temperature and fuel distributions obtained from 3D numerical simulations. To eliminate the effect of the combustion timing on dP/dθ, the in-cylinder mean temperature was regulated so that the crank angle of 50% mass fraction burned (CA50) occurs at 8° ATDC in all tested cases.

caption.p: Simulation conditions of multi-zone combustion analysis.

tr.td: Fixed at 8° ATDC by adjusting averaged temperature

sec.p: The simulation results are presented in Figure 13. The in-cylinder pressure of each case was smoothed with a filtering width of 1° CA. From this figure, it can be seen that dP/dθ with thermal stratification generated by EGR guide (Case 2) is lower than that in Case 1. Although the temperature distributions of Case 2 and Case 3 are similar to each other, dP/dθof Case 3 is much lower than that of Case 2 due to uniform fuel distribution. The in-cylinder temperature distribution generated by the EGR guide (Case 2) indicates 52% lower dP/dθmax than that with a temperature distribution generated by heat loss (Case 1). A uniform fuel concentration distribution with a temperature distribution generated by the EGR guide (Case 3) shows 36% lower dP/dθmax than that of stratified distributions of temperature and fuel concentration generated by the EGR guide (Case 2). These results indicate that a strong thermal stratification causes lower dP/dθ In addition, the EGR guide has a high potential to reduce dP/dθ by creating a strong in-cylinder thermal stratification, though the fuel distribution that has a competing effect against the temperature distribution is also formed. Hence, the upper load limit of the acceptable HCCI operation is expected to be extended using the EGR guide. It is also suggested that dP/dθ is greatly decreased by providing a uniform fuel concentration distribution with a strong thermal stratification generated by the BDSC system with the EGR guide.

caption.p: Effect of in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration on in-cylinder pressure rise rate (0D multi-zone simulations).

sec.title: High-load operating limit of an HCCI engine using the BDSC system without EGR guide
sec.p: Based on the simulation results, the effects of the BDSC and the EGR guide were experimentally investigated. At first, the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation using the BDSC system without the EGR guide was investigated in two-cylinder operation.

Figure 14 shows temporal variations of in-cylinder pressure of the HCCI operation using the BDSC system. The intake pressure, the exhaust pressure, the valve lift profiles and the mass flow rate through the intake and exhaust valves are also presented. The negative mass flow rate through the exhaust valve indicates the exhaust gas recharging flow into the cylinder. The mass flow rates through the valves were obtained from the 1D engine cycle simulations including the gas exchange process using GT-POWER. In this 1D analysis, measured intake pressure and exhaust pressure were used as boundary conditions. The measured in-cylinder pressure is also used to obtain the heat-release profile to make the cycle simulations. This method is called three pressure analysis. In the operation shown in Figure 14, the valve timing designed for the highest target load was used. The mean exhaust pressure was regulated by the exhaust throttle valve at 144 kPa (abs.) to set the CA50 at 8° ATDC. The amount of supplied fuel was set at 14.7 mg/cylinder corresponding to a net IMEP of about 450 kPa. It can be seen that the in-cylinder pressure increases up to about 170 kPa during the EGR valve opening period due to EGR gas recharging. Because the EGR gas was recharged at the intake valve closing timing, the recharged EGR gas flow has almost no effect on the intake air charging. In addition, it can be seen that the total effect of the BDSC is defined by the mean exhaust pressure and the exhaust pressure pulsation due to the exhaust blowdown pressure wave from another cylinder. Here, the effect of the BDSC is investigated focusing on the effect of blowdown pressure pulsation. Figure 15 shows the effect of the mean exhaust pressure on in-cylinder pressure at the EGR valve closing timing, PEGRC, the amount of the working gas including EGR gas and air, and the amount of the intake air. The amount of working gas is obtained from 1D engine cycle simulations. A difference between PEGRC and the mean exhaust pressure could be treated as a supercharging effect due to the blowdown pressure wave. It can be seen that PEGRC and the amount of the working gas increase with increasing the mean exhaust pressure. This indicates that the effect of the BDSC can be controlled by mean exhaust pressure. However, the supercharging effect defined by the increase in in-cylinder pressure before the compression stroke due to the blowdown pressure wave is about 25 kPa, regardless of the mean exhaust pressure. In addition, it can be seen that the mean exhaust pressure has little effect on the amount of intake air.

caption.p: Effect of the BDSC on in-cylinder pressure at the base operating condition (14.7 mg/cylinder).

Effect of mean exhaust pressure on in-cylinder pressure at EGR valve closing, the amount of intake air and the amount of working gas. The amount of working gas is calculated using a 1D engine cycle simulation.

sec.p: Next, the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation using the BDSC was investigated. The EGR guide was not applied. The valve timing for the highest target load was used. In this experiment, the amount of supplied fuel was increased with steps of about 50 kPa in net IMEP. With each amount of supplied fuel, the combustion phase was varied by adjusting the mean exhaust pressure within the range providing acceptable HCCI operation in terms of COV of IMEP and dP/dθmax. The results are presented in Figure 16. With a constant amount of supplied fuel, the increase in the mean exhaust pressure increases the amount of recharged EGR gas and in-cylinder mixture temperature. The increase in the in-cylinder temperature advanced combustion timing. This leads to the increase in dP/dθmax. In contrast, the decrease in the mean exhaust pressure retards combustion timing. Excessively delayed combustion timing deteriorates the ignition and combustion stabilities. Two contour lines, dP/dθmax = 400 kPa/° and COV of IMEP = 5%, are presented in the figure. The combustion timing between the two lines provides acceptable HCCI combustion, and the intersection of the two contour lines indicates the upper limit of acceptable HCCI operation. Note that lower load limit with this condition was not specified. The plots in the figure show measurement points. ISNOx is also shown in the bottom of the figure. It is revealed that acceptable HCCI operation at net IMEP of 480 kPa can be achieved using the BDSC. During the upper load limit operation, the charging efficiency of the intake air is about 70%, the EGR rate is about 34% and the charging efficiency of the working gas is 109%. The charging efficiency of the working gas with a naturally aspirated HCCI operation using the NVO technique was reported to be about 70%,9 and the high-load limit is about 350 kPa to 400 kPa in net IMEP.2,3,9 It can be concluded that the BDSC is capable of increasing the total amount of in-cylinder mixture without an external supercharger leading to the extension of the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation with naturally aspirated conditions. It is worth mentioning that although dP/dθmax is larger than 400 kPa/°, HCCI operation with extremely low NOx emissions could be achieved at higher IMEP values (supplied fuel of 16.4 mg/cylinder in Figure 16). This implies that the upper load limit can be extended more, if dP/dθmax can be decreased, as the limiting factor of high-load HCCI operation is dP/dθmax, in this case.

caption.p: The upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation using the BDSC and NOx emissions (low-load limit is not specified).

sec.title: Effect of EGR guide on the high-load operating limit of an HCCI engine using the BDSC system
sec.p: The effect of the EGR guide on dP/dθmax was experimentally investigated. The amount of supplied fuel was fixed at 17 mg/cylinder and 15 mg/cylinder, corresponding to a net IMEP of about 570 kPa and about 480 kPa, respectively. A net IMEP of 480 kPa is the high-load limit of HCCI operation with the BDSC. The valve timing for the highest target load was used. CA50 was varied by adjusting the mean exhaust pressure. The results are presented in Figure 17. The horizontal axis is CA50 and the vertical axis is dP/dθmax. dP/dθmax with the EGR guide is about 15% to 20% less than that without the EGR guide, probably because of a stronger thermal stratification provided by the EGR guide, as shown in the 3D simulations. Without the EGR guide, the HCCI operation with allowable dP/dθmax at net IMEP of 570 kPa cannot be attained. However, using the EGR guide, HCCI operation with net IMEP of 570 kPa with dP/dθmax of about 400 kPa/° can be achieved.

caption.p: Effect of the EGR guide on the in-cylinder pressure rise rate for high-load HCCI operation.

sec.p: The effects of the EGR guide on fuel consumption and exhaust emissions were investigated. The mean exhaust pressure was fixed at 147 kPa, and the amount of supplied fuel was varied. The results are shown in Figure 18. The black solid points indicate the operation points with unacceptable HCCI operation with larger dP/dθmax than 400 kPa/°. The effect of the EGR guide on indicated specific fuel consumption (ISFC) and exhaust emissions can be seen in Figure 18. With an acceptable HCCI operation with dP/dθmax lower than 400 kPa/°, no significant differences in ISFC and NOx emissions was found between the case with the EGR guide and the case without the EGR guide. However, for operation with dP/dθmax higher than 400 kPa/°, NOx emissions in both cases steeply increased. This is probably because the combustion temperature increases due to steep heat release. CO and HC emissions with the EGR guide are higher than those without the EGR guide. Because a relatively lower temperature zone appeared due to a strong thermal stratification with the EGR guide, combustion efficiency in the lower temperature zone may deteriorate, and HC and CO emissions would be increased.

caption.p: Effect of the EGR guide on specific fuel consumption and exhaust emissions.

sec.p: The EGR guide is demonstrated to be an effective technique to decrease dP/dθmax during high-load HCCI operation. Therefore, using the EGR guide, the upper load limit of HCCI operation, as restricted by dP/dθmax, was successfully extended. Figure 19 shows the effect of the EGR guide on the HCCI operating range with the valve timing for the highest target IMEP. Note that the low-load limit is not specified in the figure. The HCCI operating range using the BDSC without the EGR guide is also presented in the figure. Because the dP/dθmax with the EGR guide is lower than that without the EGR guide, the higher IMEP operation is realized with the EGR guide at fixed combustion timing. As a result, the high-load limit of acceptable HCCI operation was extended up to a net IMEP of about 590 kPa (gross IMEP of 620 kPa) using the EGR guide together with the BDSC. This high-load limit is much higher than the maximum load realized using the previously proposed techniques. However, the stable HCCI operation was not achieved without exhaust throttling because a high enough in-cylinder temperature to attain suitable ignition timing was not obtained without increasing the mean exhaust pressure. The increase in mean exhaust pressure increases pumping losses. Therefore, the reduction in mean exhaust pressure is an issue to be solved. The HCCI tests presented in the following subsections were conducted using the EGR guide.

caption.p: Effect of the EGR guide on the HCCI operating range and the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation with fixed valve timing (low-load limit is not specified).

sec.title: Effect of cooling water temperature on high-load operating limit of an HCCI engine using the BDSC system
sec.p: Higher cooling water temperature increases EGR gas temperature by decreasing heat loss during the expansion stroke. In addition, higher cooling water temperature decreases wall heat loss during the compression stroke. Therefore, it is considered that the temperature of the in-cylinder mixture increases,31 and the mean exhaust pressure to achieve acceptable HCCI operation using the BDSC decreases with increasing cooling water temperature. Then, the effect of cooling water temperature on the pumping loss and fuel consumption rate during the HCCI operation was investigated. The cooling water temperature was varied from 85°C to 105°C, and the valve timing for the highest target load was used. The result is shown in Figure 20. In the figure, the measurement points with the combustion timing for the best fuel consumption rate at constant amount of fuel are plotted. The combustion timing was varied by regulating the mean exhaust pressure with constant amount of fuel supply to find the timing for the best fuel consumption rate. It is revealed that the higher cooling water temperature reduces pumping mean effective pressure (PMEP) and improves fuel consumption rate, as expected. Figure 21 shows the HCCI operating ranges obtained using the valve timing for the highest target IMEP with a cooling water temperature of 85°C and 105°C. Note that the lower load limit is not specified in the figure. The amount of the supplied fuel was varied in steps of about 50 kPa in IMEP. The combustion timing was varied by regulating the mean exhaust pressure at each amount of fuel supply. As a result, it is found that the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation was almost not affected by cooling water temperature. In the previous studies,13–15 it was reported that a higher cooling water temperature generates a relatively homogenized in-cylinder temperature distribution, increasing dP/dθmax. However, as presented in Figure 21, the contour line of the dP/dθmax = 400 kPa was not affected by the cooling water temperature. In addition, it can be seen that the combustion stability during late combustion timing is improved by increasing the cooling water temperature. These are probably because the increase in cooling water temperature increases gas temperature mainly around the periphery of the chamber wall and affects the heat release during the latter part of combustion duration.16

caption.p: Effect of cooling water temperature, Tc, on PMEP and ISFC as a function of IMEP.
Effect of cooling water temperature on the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation (low-load limit is not specified).

sec.title: Effect of direct fuel injection on high-load HCCI operation
Effect of direct fuel injection on in-cylinder fuel concentration distribution
sec.p: Using the BDSC system with the EGR guide, the spatial distribution of the fuel concentration is also stratified. Figure 22 shows an example of simulated in-cylinder distributions of temperature and G/F using a PFI system with the BDSC and the EGR guide, which is obtained from the same simulations shown in Figure 11 in the previous section. The cross-sectional views of the vertical center axis of the in-cylinder temperature and the G/F distributions at 40° BTDC are presented. It can be seen that the fuel concentration in the high-temperature zone is leaner than that in the low-temperature zone. Because there is a small amount of air–fuel mixture in the high-temperature EGR gas zone, the local fuel concentration in the high-temperature EGR gas zone is relatively lean. As was discussed in the previous sections with the results of the multi-zone chemical reaction simulations (see Figure 13), it is expected that dP/dθmax decreases, and the HCCI operating range is extended by providing a uniform fuel concentration distribution with a strong thermal stratification. To attain a uniform fuel concentration distribution with a strong in-cylinder thermal stratification, a direct fuel injection system was employed. To increase the fuel concentration locally in the high-temperature and fuel-lean zone, some amount of fuel was directly injected into the high-temperature EGR gas using a direct injector attached under the intake port.

caption.p: Effect of the EGR guide on spatial distributions of temperature and G/F (3D simulations).

sec.p: Firstly, the effect of fuel injection timing on the in-cylinder distribution of fuel concentration was investigated via 3D numerical simulations. In the simulations, the total amount of supplied fuel was fixed at 15.8 mg/cylinder, and 20% of the supplied fuel was directly injected into the cylinder while 80% of the total supplied fuel was injected into the intake port before intake valve opening. The calculation conditions are summarized in Table 4. Three different fuel injection conditions were examined. In Case 1, DI is not used. In this case, all fuel is supplied into the intake port, and a fully premixed intake air–fuel mixture is provided. In Case 2, 20% of the supplied fuel is directly injected into the cylinder during the compression stroke. The end of the direct fuel injection timing is set at −165° ATDC. In this case, fuel is injected towards the recharged EGR gas zone to increase the fuel concentration in the high-temperature zone. In Case 3, 20% of the total supplied fuel is injected into the cylinder at 300° ATDC during the exhaust stroke. In the BDSC system, exhaust gas pushed out from the cylinder to the exhaust port is charged into the cylinder again at the beginning of the compression stroke. Therefore, the directly injected fuel into the burnt gas during the exhaust stroke is supposed to be pushed back into the cylinder together with the recharged EGR gas during the next cycle. Because fuel and EGR gas can be well mixed, the fuel concentration distribution would be more uniform.

caption.p: Conditions for calculating the effect of DI on in-cylinder fuel distribution.

sec.p: The simulation results are shown in Figure 23. The frequency distribution of the in-cylinder mixture in terms of fuel concentration and temperature is shown. The vertical axis shows the mixture temperature and the horizontal axis shows the mass ratio of fuel to working gas (F/G). The color bar indicates the mass fraction of the mixture. It is found that injection during the compression stroke (Case 2) provides the most stratified fuel distribution. In this case, the fuel concentration shows a broader distribution than that in the case without DI (Case 1). By contrast, exhaust stroke injection (Case 3) provides a more uniform fuel distribution while keeping a broad temperature distribution. From these results, it is found that a small amount of fuel injection directly into the cylinder during the exhaust stroke is effective at generating a homogenized fuel concentration distribution with strong thermal stratification.

caption.p: Effect of direct fuel injection timing on in-cylinder distributions of temperature and fuel concentration (3D simulations).

sec.title: Effect of direct fuel injection on the high-load operating limit of an HCCI engine using the BDSC system
sec.p: Based on the simulation results, the effect of direct fuel injection on dP/dθmax was experimentally investigated. Table 5 shows the fuel injection conditions. The amount of directly injected fuel and the direct fuel injection timing were varied with a constant total amount of supplied fuel. The injection timing shown in this table is the timing of the end of injection (EOI).

caption.p: Conditions for DI and PFI.

tr.td: DI fuel mass ratio to total amount of supplied fuel

sec.p: Firstly, DI timing was varied. The total amount of supplied fuel was 15.4 mg/cylinder, and 20% of the supplied fuel was directly injected into the cylinder, whereas 80% of the supplied fuel was injected into the intake port before the intake valve opens. The mean exhaust pressure was set at 138 kPa (abs.). The results are shown in Figure 24. The effect of DI timing on dP/dθmax, COV of IMEP, CA50 and exhaust emissions can be seen in this figure. With the direct fuel injection after 320° ATDC during the exhaust stroke, dP/dθmax decreases without increasing NOx and HC emissions. In addition, CA50 is retarded. With direct fuel injection before 320° ATDC during the exhaust stroke, although dP/dθmax decreases, HC emissions increase with an advance in the DI timing. This is because the fuel would not be recharged due to excessively earlier injection timing than the exhaust valve reopening. When 20% of the total fuel is directly injected during the compression stroke, dP/dθmax decreases and CA50 is delayed without increasing NOx or HC emissions as the DI is retarded up to −100° ATDC. Meanwhile, when the injection timing is retarded much later than 100° BTDC, dP/dθmax and NOx emissions steeply increase and CA50 is advanced. 3D calculations were carried out to investigate the spatial distribution of fuel concentration. When fuel is injected at −40° ATDC, the fuel spray impinged on the piston top, forming a local fuel-rich zone. With this local fuel-rich zone, as autoignition occurs early, combustion temperature increases and the NOx emissions increase. With direct fuel injection during the intake stroke, dP/dθmax and exhaust emissions are not affected by ignition timing.

caption.p: Effect of direct fuel injection timing on in-cylinder pressure rise rate, CA50 and exhaust emissions (DI : PFI = 20 : 80).

sec.p: Next, the effect of the amount of DI fuel on dP/dθmax and exhaust emissions was investigated. The total amount of supplied fuel was fixed at 15.2 mg/cylinder. Two different DI timings were examined: one was −100° ATDC during the compression stroke and the other was 310° ATDC during the exhaust stroke. At these two injection timings, the lowest dP/dθmax without an increase in exhaust emissions was obtained in the previous experiment shown in Figure 24. The results with a compression stroke injection (EOI = −100° ATDC) can be seen in Figure 25. The horizontal axis is the mass ratio of the directly injected fuel to the total amount of supplied fuel. By increasing the amount of the DI fuel, CA50 is advanced, while dP/dθmax and NOx emissions increase. This is because an increase in the DI fuel during the compression stroke enhances fuel stratification. Due to a generation of relatively fuel-rich zones, ignition timing advances and dP/dθmax increases. HC emissions are not affected by the DI fuel amount. The results with an exhaust stroke injection (EOI = 310° ATDC) are shown in Figure 26. It is found that dP/dθmax, CA50 and NOx emissions are not affected by the amount of directly injected fuel. However, HC emissions increase with increasing amount of DI fuel. When the injection duration increases with fixed EOI timing, the start of injection timing is advanced. With an early start of injection, the fuel directly injected at the early stage of the injection period would not be recharged into the cylinder, thereby HC emissions increase with increasing amount of DI fuel.

caption.p: Effect of mass fraction of DI fuel to total supplied fuel on in-cylinder pressure rise rate, ignition timing (CA50) and exhaust emissions with DI at −100° ATDC during the compression stroke.
Effect of mass fraction of DI fuel to total supplied fuel on in-cylinder pressure rise rate, ignition timing (CA50) and exhaust emissions with DI at 310° ATDC during the exhaust stroke.

sec.p: From these results, it is found that direct fuel injection timing and the amount of DI fuel largely affects combustion timing (CA50), which largely affects dP/dθmax. To eliminate the effect of the combustion timing and to clarify the effect of in-cylinder fuel concentration distribution provided by the direct fuel injection on dP/dθmax, the correlation between dP/dθmax and CA50 was investigated. The results are shown in Figure 27. The experimental results shown in Figure 24 are replotted. The vertical axis is dP/dθmax and the horizontal axis is CA50. There is no significant difference in dP/dθmax between the different fuel injection timings. This indicates that dP/dθmax is decreased mainly due to the delay in combustion phase (CA50) when direct fuel injection is used.

caption.p: Correlation between dP/dθmax and CA50 with injection timing as a parameter.

sec.p: According to the simulation results, some amount of fuel injection during the exhaust stroke could provide a homogeneous distribution of fuel concentration and reduce dP/dθmax. However, dP/dθmax was not affected significantly by the direct fuel injection. Figure 28 shows frequency distributions of the in-cylinder temperature and fuel concentration at −20° ATDC with direct fuel injection during the exhaust stroke calculated by the 3D numerical simulations. It can be seen that the fuel concentration with the exhaust stroke injection is more homogeneous than that without DI. However, the in-cylinder temperature distribution with the exhaust stroke injection is also more homogeneous than that without DI. With the exhaust stroke injection, the amount of high-temperature gas decreases and the amount of medium-temperature gas increases. Namely, the DI during the exhaust stroke decreases recharged EGR gas temperature. As a result, the temperature difference between the intake mixture and EGR gas is decreased, and the temperature distribution becomes more homogeneous. The effect of a uniform fuel concentration on dP/dθmax would be canceled out by the effect of relatively uniform in-cylinder temperature distribution on dP/dθmax.

caption.p: Effect of DI during the exhaust stroke on in-cylinder temperature and fuel concentration distributions (3D simulations).

sec.p: Next, the effect of the DI on the upper load limit of the HCCI was investigated. The results are presented in Figure 29. The operating range obtained with the DI at −100° ATDC is shown. Twenty per cent of the supplied fuel was directly injected into the cylinder. ISNOx is also presented in the bottom of the figure. As the correlation between dP/dθmax and CA50 is not affected by the DI, the HCCI operating range defined by the dP/dθmax and COV of IMEP with the direct fuel injection is similar to the case with the PFI. However, the direct fuel injection slightly increases NOx emissions around the upper load limit, probably due to a slightly stratified fuel distribution. Thereby, high-load HCCI operation with direct fuel injection is limited by NOx emissions. The HCCI operating range is presented in Figure 30. The mean exhaust pressure and EGR rate required for the HCCI operation are shown on the horizontal axis. Compared to the case without DI (PFI 100%), acceptable HCCI operation with the DI is attained with higher mean exhaust pressure. Because directly injected fuel decreases the in-cylinder mixture temperature, a larger amount of EGR gas is required to achieve HCCI operation. When only PFI is used, the acceptable HCCI operation around the upper load limit is achieved with a limited exhaust pressure range. This means that the operational robustness around the upper load limit is low. Using direct fuel injection combined with PFI, the operational HCCI is attained with a relatively wider exhaust pressure range. It is considered that direct fuel injection has a possibility to improve the operational robustness for high-load HCCI operation.

caption.p: Effect of DI during the compression stroke on the HCCI operating range and the upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation with fixed valve timing (low-load limit is not specified).
Effect of DI during the compression stroke on the HCCI operating range and mean exhaust pressure required for the HCCI operation (low-load limit is not specified).

sec.title: Extension of high-load operating limit of an HCCI engine with multi-cylinder operation
Reduction in cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing using secondary air injection
sec.p: The experiments presented in the previous subsections were conducted focusing on only one cylinder among four cylinders. Considering a multi-cylinder HCCI operation, the cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing is one of the limiting factors of the HCCI operation.24 Controlling the ignition timing of each cylinder in each cycle is important. To achieve this, a secondary air injection system was proposed and examined. In this system, secondary air was injected into the exhaust port before the EGR valve closes to control the recharged EGR gas temperature. The injection pressure of the secondary air was set at 250 kPa (gauge). Table 6 shows the secondary air injection conditions.

caption.p: Secondary air injection conditions.

sec.p: Firstly, the effect of secondary air injection on ignition timing was investigated with two-cylinder operation. The air injection duration was varied to control the amount of air. Figure 31 shows the effect of secondary air injection on the heat-release rate. The IMEP is about 485 kPa. It can be seen that the combustion phase retards and the combustion duration increases when the amount of air is increased. Figure 32 shows the effect of the amount of air on CA50 for high-load HCCI operation with a net IMEP of 485 kPa. As shown in this figure, CA50 retards when the amount of air is increased, until misfiring occurs. Next, secondary air injection was applied to reduce cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing. Because the ignition timing of cylinder 1 was earlier than that of cylinder 4, the air injection duration for cylinder 1 was varied to adjust the ignition timing of cylinder 1 to that of cylinder 4. The results are presented in Figure 33. It can be seen that when using the secondary air, there is almost no difference in the heat-release rate between cylinder 1 and cylinder 4. Secondary air injection is validated as an effective technique to reduce cylinder-to-cylinder variations of the ignition and combustion.

caption.p: Effect of secondary air injection into the exhaust port on the heat-release rate.
Effect of secondary air injection amount on ignition timing.
Effect of secondary air injection on cylinder-to-cylinder variation in the heat-release rate (IMEPnet = 530 kPa).

sec.p: Finally, the secondary air injection system was applied to four-cylinder operation to see the effect of reduction in cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing on the operating range of the multi-cylinder HCCI engine. Figure 34 shows the effect of secondary air injection on the upper load limit of the HCCI operation with fixed valve timing. The net IMEP on the vertical axis is the averaged net IMEP between the four cylinders. Without secondary air injection, the upper load limit is a net IMEP of 520 kPa, which is about 12% lower than that obtained with two-cylinder operation. From Figure 34, it can be seen that the operating range with four-cylinder operation is mainly restricted by the cylinder with the lowest combustion stability. With the reduction in cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing by secondary air injection, the upper load limit is successfully extended up to a net IMEP of 570 kPa (BMEP of about 520 kPa), which is slightly lower than that obtained with the two-cylinder operation. The effect of secondary air on fuel consumption and exhaust emissions can be seen in Figure 35. Fuel consumption and exhaust emissions are little affected by secondary air injection. However, it should be noted that when secondary air injection is used, brake thermal efficiency would be decreased. When the secondary air is injected with an injection duration of 8.0 ms (about 16cm3/cylinder) and an injection pressure of 350 kPa (abs.) for four cylinders, as shown in Figure 33, the work required for secondary air injection is roughly estimated to be about 250 W. With a high-load HCCI operation with a BMEP of 520 kPa and engine speed of 1500 r/min, output from the test engine used in this study (displacement volume of 1998 cm3) is about 13 kW. So, the energy used for secondary air injection is estimated to be about 2% of the engine output in this case.

caption.p: Effect of reduction in cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing using the secondary injection timing on the HCCI operating range and the upper load limit of the acceptable HCCI operation for four-cylinder operation (low-load limit is not specified).
Effect of secondary air injection on ISFC and exhaust emissions.

sec.p: Using secondary air injection, cylinder-to-cylinder variation is successfully reduced and the upper load limit of operational four-cylinder HCCI is extended without any disadvantages in exhaust emissions. Additionally, the gas fuel injector has a high enough responsivity to control the injection duration in each cycle. Therefore, the secondary air injection system is expected to also be applied to reduce a cycle-to-cycle variation of ignition timing.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: To extend the operating range of a gasoline-fueled multi-cylinder HCCI engine, a BDSC system and an EGR guide were developed. The concept was to obtain a large amount of working gas, consisting of air and EGR gas, and strong in-cylinder thermal stratification without an external supercharger for extending the upper load limit of HCCI operation, whilst keeping dP/dθmax and NOx emissions low. Additionally, to reduce cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing with a multi-cylinder HCCI operation, a secondary air injection system, which independently controlled the recharged EGR gas temperature and the ignition timing of each cylinder, was applied. The effects of the proposed systems on the HCCI operating range were numerically and experimentally examined. As a result, the following conclusions were obtained.

list-item.p: Using the BDSC system, together with the EGR guide, dP/dθmax during high-load HCCI operations could be decreased because a large amount of in-cylinder working gas and a strong thermal stratification would be provided. As a result, the high-load limit of the HCCI operating range was successfully extended up to a net IMEP of 590 kPa (gross IMEP of 615 kPa) for naturally aspirated conditions with limits of dP/dθmax≤ 400 kPa/°, COV of IMEP ≤ 5% and ISNOx≤ 0.1 g/kWh. However, to achieve stable HCCI operation by using the BDSC system, the effect of the exhaust blowdown pressure on EGR gas recharging has to be enhanced by increasing the mean exhaust pressure. This increase in mean exhaust pressure decreases the fuel consumption rate due to an increase in pumping loss.

A higher cooling water temperature could decrease the mean exhaust pressure to achieve acceptable HCCI operation using the BDSC system. As a result, the fuel consumption rate was improved by increasing the cooling water temperature, mainly due to a reduction in pumping loss.

When some amount of supplied fuel was directly injected into the cylinder during the beginning of the compression stroke or the end of exhaust stroke, ignition timing was retarded and dP/dθmax was decreased due to the decrease in in-cylinder temperature. Direct fuel injection slightly increased NOx emissions. The upper load limit of acceptable HCCI operation with direct fuel injection was restricted by NOx emissions. In addition, the mean exhaust pressure required for acceptable HCCI operation is shifted to a higher pressure range with direct fuel injection, leading to an improvement of the robustness of HCCI operation.

The cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing restricts the operating range for a multi-cylinder HCCI operation. Using secondary air injection, the cylinder-to-cylinder variation in ignition timing was reduced and the upper load limit of the four-cylinder HCCI operation was successfully extended up to a net IMEP of 570 kPa for naturally aspirated conditions without any disadvantages in exhaust emissions.

sec.title: IMEP
sec.p: IMEP is a measure of the work done by the gas on the piston per unit volume of the cylinder during one engine cycle. There are two kinds of IMEP: net IMEP and gross IMEP. Net IMEP refers to the work throughout the intake, compression, expansion and exhaust strokes, while gross IMEP refers only to the work during the compression and expansion strokes. Gross IMEP differs from net IMEP by ignoring pumping losses (pumping mean effective pressure; PMEP) during the exhaust and intake strokes.
